awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:Element: Development of MuST, A Multiple Scattering Theory based Computational Software for First Principles Approach to Disordered Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The effect of disorder in materials is of great fundamental and technological interest. Disorder disrupts the periodic arrangement of atoms in perfect materials. It profoundly affects materials properties and can provide a valuable tool in changing and controlling their physical properties. The best-known example is the transistor and other silicon components which are controlled through the introduction of disorder. Quantum mechanical states in semiconductors induced by introducing impurities and disorder can dramatically increase the efficiency of solar cells. There are many other materials of potential technological interest, such as high entropy alloys, dilute magnetic semiconductors, and topological insulators where disorder plays an essential role. Being able to understand, control, and predict the disorder effects in real physical systems is essential for the development of new structural and functional materials for future technological applications. This project involves building computer software that is aimed to enable the study of disorder effects using the principles of quantum mechanics and to accelerate the discovery of materials essential for industry and information technology applications. The creation of a large community of users and developers who will accelerate this process is envisioned. This project supports interdisciplinary training and education of undergraduate and graduate students in the fields of theoretical condensed matter physics and computational materials sciences. The user community of this software will be supported through webinars, discussion groups on social media, and online tutorial materials. This award supports various training and outreach efforts, including an annual "Beowulf Boot Camp" and "Quantum Day" for high-school students, and undergraduate and graduate research opportunities. 

The PIs will build upon and unify decades of development of research codes for the first-principles investigation of disordered materials. These codes include the Korringa-Kohn-Rostoker Coherent Potential Approximation, which is the first principles code for the study of random alloys, and the Locally Self-consistent Multiple Scattering code, which can enable the study of extremely large disordered systems from first principles using the largest parallel supercomputers available. Strong disorder effects and Anderson localization have been studied on the model Hamiltonian level using the Typical Medium Dynamical Cluster Approximation (TMDCA). To enable the study the strong disorder effects in real system within the first-principles Locally Self-consistent Multiple Scattering formalism with cluster embedding, the project team will use the typical medium analysis of TMDCA. The software product of this project, MuST, will be made available on GitHub as a self-contained open source package with detailed online documentations. MuST will create a scalable approach for first principles studies of quantum materials that efficiently utilizes petascale and future high-performance computing resources. It will expand the user community by enabling researchers within academia and industry to perform calculations that are presently out of reach for most users. MuST will provide a computational framework for the investigation of phase transitions and electron localization in the presence of disorder in real materials and will also enable the computational study of local chemical correlation effects on the magnetic structure, phase stability, and mechanical properties of high entropy alloys and other disordered structures.

This award is jointly supported by the NSF Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure and the Division of Materials Research within the NSF Directorate of Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Disorder, in the form of impurities and various imperfections, is not only inevitable in real materials but also profoundly influences their properties, offering a valuable means of altering and controlling their physical characteristics. At its most fundamental level, disorder disrupts the inherent translational symmetry found in ordered substances and compounds, leading to alterations in atomic, electronic, magnetic, optical, and phonon properties. One well-known example is the utilization of disorder in transistors and other silicon components, where introducing disorder allows for precise control of their electronics properties. Another significant manifestation of disorder's impact is electron localization, also known as Anderson localization. There exist numerous other systems, such as high entropy alloys, dilute magnetic semiconductors, topological insulator materials, quantum criticality, and various condensed matter physics phenomena, where disorder plays an indispensable role. Comprehending, managing, and predicting the effects of disorder in real materials is of paramount importance both in terms of fundamental research and technological advancements crucial for developing novel materials that will find applications in future technologies.

To predict material properties from first principles based on quantum mechanics, a state-of-the-art approach involves solving a one-electron Schrodinger equation, also known as the Kohn-Sham equation, utilizing a local density approximation (or a generalized gradient approximation) within the framework of density functional theory (DFT). This project, as described on the project homepage https://must-project.github.io/Webpage/, aims to develop a software package for solving the Kohn-Sham equation for disordered systems. Its primary objectives are to create US-based open-source code, enabling computational studies of disorder effects using quantum mechanics principles, to expedite the discovery of materials crucial for applications in industry and information technology, and ultimately to foster a thriving community of users and developers to accelerate this progress.

Our software product, MuST, named after the underlying methodology Multiple Scattering Theory used for solving the Kohn-Sham equation, was initially released in October 2019. It is now available for the research community to download from GitHub (https://github.com/mstsuite/MuST). MuST is designed to facilitate ab initio investigations of solid-state materials with disorder and implements several Green's function-based computational methodologies. These methodologies include: a) the full-potential Korringa-Kohn-Rostoker (KKR) method, used for electronic structure calculations of ordered structures (e.g., Al, CuZn in B2 structure, and Si); b) the Korringa-Kohn-Rostoker Coherent Potential Approximation (KKR-CPA) method for simulating random alloys (e.g., INVAR alloys, high entropy alloys); c)  the Locally Self-consistent Multiple Scattering (LSMS) method for large supercells (N > 10,000 atoms) simulating disordered structures (e.g., amorphous metals, quasicrystals, doped quantum materials). Furthermore, the MuST package incorporates the Kubo-Greenwood formula, enabling electronic transport calculations. This functionality allows the determination of the electric conductivity of disordered structures from first principles. Throughout the course of this project, MuST has undergone numerous software updates and releases, progressing from version 1.0.0 to version 1.9.0.

Researchers now apply MuST in electronic structure calculations for disordered materials, studying phase stability, Coulomb field fluctuation, magnetic properties, and electrical conductivity in alloys. The high-performance LSMS method supports machine learning and investigates localization effects due to defects. LSMS combined with the Typical Medium Dynamical Cluster Approximation (TMDCA) offers scalable first principles studies of quantum materials with strong disorder and localization effects.

In 2022, MuST was selected for the ``Characteristic Science Applications'' award by the Texas Advanced Computing Center (TACC) from 140 candidates. Chosen based on scientific significance, representation of future computing facilities, and current capabilities, this award enhances MuST's performance on High-Performance Computing (HPC) facilities, aiding benchmark development and showcasing broader impact. Most importantly, it positions MuST in the planning and early science program for the future LCCF.

Educational and outreach efforts are integral to our project, providing interdisciplinary research training for undergraduate and graduate students in theoretical condensed matter physics and computational materials sciences. We have supported four graduate students and three postdocs, along with mentoring a dozen undergraduates engaged in computational research at MuST institutions. This mentorship hones their programming and data analysis skills, making them valuable in academic and industrial settings, with many presenting their research at conferences. To support our user community, we conduct webinars, facilitate online discussion groups, and create tutorial resources. Our ``MuST Program for Disordered Materials'' YouTube Channel (https://www.youtube.com/@MuST-Program) features 43 video recordings, including lectures, presentations, and tutorials related to disordered materials and numerical simulation methods. By the end of 2023, it gained 580 subscribers and 500,000+ views. Our MuST collaboration expanded to other institutions and researchers across the USA, fostering a growing MuST user community. Finally, aligned with our commitment to outreach, we organize annual events such as ``Physics Fun" for middle and high-school female students, ``Quantum Day" for high-school students, workshops for NSF-REU students and women in STEM, and a workshop on modeling quantum materials with disorder for teachers.
